mainmatter.p: A category is said to be small if it has a samll set (i.e. a set but not a proper class) of objects and morphisms. In other words a small category is an internal category in category of sets.
This note is about the category theory and its applications. Instead of reading a well-organized book, I prefer to write down the things I learned from ncatlab and papers.

tree.mainmatter:
Intuitively, a category is a collection of objects and arrows between them, such arrows can be composed and there is an identity arrow for each object.
There are commonly two ways to define a category, which are equivalent in usual foundations of mathematics. One of them generalizes the notion of internal category nicely while the other one is more convenient for enriched category.
The major difference is whether they use a single collection of all morphisms or several collections of morphisms (family of collections indexed by pairs of objects)

A category CCCC consists A collection of objects C_0C0C_0C0​ (\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)). A collection C_1C1C_1C1​ (\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)) of morphisms (arrows). For every morphism ffff there are an object s(f)s(f)s(f)s(f) (source, domain) and an object t(f)t(f)t(f)t(f) (target, codomain). For every pair of morphisms f, gf,gf, gf,g such that t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g)t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g), there is a morphism g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f (composition) (Also written gfgfgfgf or f;gf;gf;gf;g). For every object xxxx, there is a morphism \text {id} _xidx\text {id} _xidx​ (or 1_x1x1_x1x​) called identity. The following properties hold: s(g \circ f) = s(f)s(g∘f)=s(f)s(g \circ f) = s(f)s(g∘f)=s(f) and t(g \circ f) = t(g)t(g∘f)=t(g)t(g \circ f) = t(g)t(g∘f)=t(g). s(1_x) = xs(1x)=xs(1_x) = xs(1x​)=x and t(1_x) = xt(1x)=xt(1_x) = xt(1x​)=x. Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘fh \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘f when t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g)t(f) = s(g)t(f)=s(g), and t(g) = s(h)t(g)=s(h)t(g) = s(h)t(g)=s(h). Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx=ff \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx​=f and \text {id} _y \circ f = fidy∘f=f\text {id} _y \circ f = fidy​∘f=f If the identity map and its axioms are omitted then one speaks of a semicategory.

title.strong: With a family of collections of morphisms

tree.mainmatter: A category CCCC consists A collection of objects C_0C0C_0C0​ (\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)\text {Ob} (C)Ob(C)). For every pair of objects x, yx,yx, yx,y, a collection C_1(x, y)C1(x,y)C_1(x, y)C1​(x,y) (\hom _C(x,y)hom⁡C(x,y)\hom _C(x,y)homC​(x,y)) of morphisms from xxxx to yyyy. For each pair of morphisms ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y) and gggg in C_1(y,z)C1(y,z)C_1(y,z)C1​(y,z), a morphism g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f in C_1(x,z)C1(x,z)C_1(x,z)C1​(x,z). called their composition. For each object xxxx, a morphism \text {id} _xidx\text {id} _xidx​ in C_1(x,x)C1(x,x)C_1(x,x)C1​(x,x) called the identity on xxxx. The following properties hold: Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘fh \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ fh∘(g∘f)=(h∘g)∘f for all ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y), gggg in C_1(y,z)C1(y,z)C_1(y,z)C1​(y,z), and hhhh in C_1(z,w)C1(z,w)C_1(z,w)C1​(z,w). Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx=ff \circ \text {id} _x = ff∘idx​=f and \text {id} _y \circ f = fidy∘f=f\text {id} _y \circ f = fidy​∘f=f for all ffff in C_1(x,y)C1(x,y)C_1(x,y)C1​(x,y). Usually we write \text {Mor} (C)Mor(C)\text {Mor} (C)Mor(C) for the disjoint union \bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y)⨆x,y∈C0C1(x,y)\bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y)⨆x,y∈C0​​C1​(x,y).

mainmatter.p: Its common to talk about some objects and their morphisms. Informally, a diagram in a category CCCC consists of some objects of CCCC connected by some morphisms of CCCC.
This terminology is often used when speaking about limits or colimits of a diagram.
One formal way to define a diagram is to use a functor from a (very) small category to CCCC. That is, a functor whose domain is a small category.
A category is said to be small if it has a samll set (i.e. a set but not a proper class) of objects and morphisms. In other words a small category is an internal category in category of sets.

We did not explain what a functor is, but it is very natural thought. Briefly, a functor is a homomorphism between two categories. It maps objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms, preserving the structure of the categories.

A functor FFFF from a category CCCC to a category DDDD is a map sending each x \in Cx∈Cx \in Cx∈C to an object F(x) \in DF(x)∈DF(x) \in DF(x)∈D and each morphism f:x \to yf:x→yf:x \to yf:x→y in CCCC to morphism F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y)F(f):F(x) \to F(y)F(f):F(x)→F(y) in DDDD, such that Composition is preserved: F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f)F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)F(g∘f)=F(g)∘F(f). Identity is preserved: F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx)=idF(x)F( \text {id} _x) = \text {id} _{F(x)}F(idx​)=idF(x)​.
For the sake of completeness, we state the definition of the functor category and the natural transformations between functors.

Let CCCC and DDDD be categories, the functor category D^CDCD^CDC (or [C,D][C,D][C,D][C,D]) is the category whose objects are functors from CCCC to DDDD. morphisms are natural transformations between functors.
We state the concise functorial definition of diagrams of the shape of categories.

Let CCCC be a category and JJJJ be a small category. A diagram of shape JJJJ in CCCC is a functor X:J \to CX:J→CX:J \to CX:J→C. The category of JJJJ-shaped diagrams in CCCC is the functor category C^JCJC^JCJ.

A limit of a diagram F:D \to CF:D→CF:D \to CF:D→C is an object \lim Flim⁡F\lim FlimF of CCCC equipped with morphisms to the objects F(d)F(d)F(d)F(d) for all d \in Dd∈Dd \in Dd∈D, such that everything in sight commutes.
